newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Six Nigerian companies sign up for natural gas.
newsitem.headline: Six Nigerian companies sign up for natural gas.

text.p: Six Nigerian firms have signed up to receive natural gas from a pipeline which will open in February 1998 linking the main business district in Lagos with a southern oil and gas field, the Nigerian Gas Company said on Friday.
The state-run company's managing director, Jackson Giaus-Obaseki, told journalists the companies are Cadbury, Dunlop, PZ Industries, Que Metals, Federated Steel Industries and Kolorkote Nig.Ltd.

The spur line, built at a cost of $18 million dollars, links the Ikeja business district of the commercial capital with a pipeline already running from Royal Dutch/Shell oil fields to the principal power station in Lagos.
Giaus-Obaseki said the new pipeline would deliver 50 million standard cubic feet of gas per day to the six companies.

"But this can always be increased if the need arises as the main line has the capacity to carry 600 million standard cubic feet of gas per day," he said, adding that the companies would save around 30 percent on current bills for liquid fuels.
Nigeria is trying to encourage the use of gas associated with oil production. Around two billion standard cubic feet of gas are produced per day, but 75 percent is flared.
